reviewText:
Remember these days people? When games were just about violence?  Postal, Doom, etc.  Where it was just to murder everything in your path regardless of who it was or what it has done etc.  Well those days are gone! Now we have a game that is nothing but that! Quite litterally.

PROS:

Fun Gameplay: This game is nothing but murdering everything from the dandelions on upwards in any household that some random dude on the phone tells you to do regardless of if you want to but I guess that's because it's half the fun.  Running into some random person's building and just bashing everyones skulls in or shooting them up with a gun till all of their guts spill out or their head gets blown off.

Masks: Each mask has a different ability, which I thought was a neat little mechanic for the game since each level can be played a little differently each time with it's own abilities.  Like Dennis starts with a free knife, Peter has silent bullets but somehow some people aren't fully def or something, Ted means dogs won't even care that you're there or murdering their owners, etc.

Story: As far as the story goes it's neat I suppose, where random things happen like you get put into some room talking to 3 people wearing a horse, rooster, and owl mask which I'm STILL convinced this is basically your subconcious or something.  And later when it's hard to tell what's real and what's fake since everything seems the same with the 80's vibe around the game with the colors and areas you go to.

Soundtrack: This is one of the few things that got me into this game was the really catchy soundtrack, one of my friends showed the Knock" song to me and I instantly got hooked onto the rest of the soundtrack.  Granted some I don't really like but the large majority of them I do.  I keep hearing the 2nd game has a hit and miss soundtrack which I kind of agree on since some of the songs are great where others just sound weird and boring
date: or way too pumped instead of being the mellow music this game has.\n\nRight back in the action: Instead of going through a REALLY long loading time when you die it's a instant reload into the area with no waiting
recommended: making sure you get right back into the action without you having to get too bored and lose the tension too quickly if at all.\n\nSatisfying after levels: I was trying to be strategic in most of the levels

reviewText:
An amazing jump in the late 80's, Hotline Miami is an action game based on rapidity and fast choices, realized in a perfect retro style.
The gameplay is immediate but hard to master, because level progression follows a perfect slope of increasing difficulty. Enemy AI is often unpredictable, granting a lively gaming experience.
The plot is intriguing and well narrated; nothing is left to chance and attention to details is always crucial.
Soundtrack is a masterpiece, as every track perfectly suits the atmosphere and game style.

82/100

reviewText: Hotline Miami is a beautifully made, horrifyingly violent, incredible mess of gunshots and gore. The art style, coupled with the amazing soundtrack, completely captures the 1980's setting and mood. The graphics are beautiful and the game runs as smooth as butter (and I can't believe it's NOT butter! It's Hotline Miami). The gameplay fully envelops your attention and is extremely difficult. The levels are designed perfectly and allow you to plan your next moves strategically. And even though most of the game's levels will take you at least ten tries minimum, you probably won't even be mad simply because of the game's perfect execution of a fast-paced hardcore bloody top-down shooter. I highly suggest Hotline Miami to anyone with $9.99 (or $3.99, because it was on sale when I wrote this) that's willing to get more than their money's worth. Worth every cent. 1989/10.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
What can I say? Hotline Miami puts you into the mind of a maniac as you travel around the city of Miami in the 1980s slaughtering gangsters in an extremely gory fashion. The primitive graphics do not reduce the visceral nature of the gore; in fact, it adds to the disturbing effect it will have on you since it all plays into the theme of hallucination and sanity present.

If you liked the music in the movie Drive, you will like this game's soundtrack as well. Splatter people to some very Kavinsky-ish tunes!

If you are a fan of old school arcade games, ultra violence, or 80s new wave music, get Hotline Miami.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Intense, action-packed, fast-paced 2-d pixel art 80's Miami action. Excellent music that could have been straight from Miami Vice, eye candy visuals and crisp gameplay pack for one solid, top-down shooter. An abstract story that left me thinking hours after I finished. Fun challenging gameplay that feels very tactical. You can go down with one shot, making the game all about planning your moves before executing them, and it is difficult, but the completion feels ever so satisfying. Its perfect at what it does leaving the only demand being more. Thankfully it has highscores, a large variety unlockables and achievements to deliver just that. Though there is enough variety in the weapons, there could have been more weapon types aside from just melee and ranged. Perhaps weapons that could be setup, like mines or tripwires. It would mix up the pace of the game a little. Aside from that it is one of my favourite top down shooters ever. 8/10
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is visually reminiscent of the top down GTA games. Hotline Miami alternates between story and violent (albeit pixelated) combat, giving this game an unusual spin.

The gameplay can be challenging but is always satisfying, especially when clearing a stage you've struggled with. The game mechanics are basic but well executed, albeit on the rare occasion frustrating. The combo system provides a pleasing extra level of depth to combat.

One of the most striking parts of the game is the music, which suits the gameplay perfectly. A blend of 80's house music and chip tunes locks in with the gameplay, creating a rythmic flow to a murderous rampage.

A must play.

reviewText:
I get the appeal of this game. You come home from a rough day at work, your crack♥♥♥♥♥ is dead and bleeding all over your favorite couch, you're out of milk & cocaine, and you just need some YOU time. Unfortunately, it is still illegal to go around prying people open with crowbars. For ten bucks ($5.00 today) you can play Hotline Miami to get all that rage out in a healthier manner in place of getting your unlubed ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ violently pounded in prison for the rest of your 114-year sentence.

If you're like me and you walk into sketchy establishments unarmed and manage to kill everyone inside, relying primarily on doors and flinging guns at suited dip♥♥♥♥♥ all while wearing a creepy horse mask, then you should probably just skip this game. It's gonna feel like Tuesday to you.

For those of you who enjoy good chiptune music, violently bashing 8bit people into sprays of red, and a challenge that may inspire you on your next murdering spree I have words for you- BUY THIS F***ING GAME.

reviewText:
I'm very conflicted about whether or not I think Hotline Miami 2 is a good game, but I'm 100% certain I had a hell of a time with Hotline Miami 1. It was a blast from start to finish, and I'd say it's safe to assume it left some...

LASTING IMPRESSIONS
Hotline Miami

GENRE
Top Down Shooter-Slasher/Action

STORY
In Hotline Miami you play as the fan-named delusional psychopath Jacket. His name is Jacket due to his distinctive letterman jacket that he wears. [Glasses, jacket, shirt, call me glasses-jacket-shirt man.] When the game begins, you find yourself in a dark, dirty room with a door directly in front of you. As you step through the door, you're greeted by three figures wearing different animal masks. The woman in the horse mask seems concerned for your mental health; saying it might be better if you didn't remember your actions or identity. The man in the owl mask, dressed like a Russian mobster,  begins to yell at you; disgusted at your behavior and presence.  However, the man in the rooster mask, dressed in the same clothes you are, says he knows you. He asks if the date 'April 3rd, 1989' means anything to you. You then wake up in your rundown apartment room to the sound of a phone ringing...

GAMEPLAY
Hotline Miami is a game about pulse-pounding, high adrenaline combat. When you play you have to be on gaurd, on point, and on your toes; lest ye suffer a swift death. Everyone in this game dies in one hit; that includes you. Levels are set up by floors, with the next floor becoming accessible when you're the only person remaining with your brains firmly inside your cranium. You'll start out with your fists as weapons, but your fist can only knock enemies down onto the floor or up against walls. If you hit an enemy they'll drop their weapon; which you can promptly pick up and use to re-arrange their facial structure. Weapons range from close range objects such as bats, pipes, or knives; to long range weapons such as guns, throwing stars, or maybe even a plain old brick. [Brick too OP please nerf.] Hotline Miami is also a game about getting a good highscore; like back in the arcade ages. Each kill, maneuver, door-knockdown, execution, and combo will net you some points. It's a good idea to try and rack up a good combo and vary up your playstyle, as highscores unlock masks and points from the aforementioned scores will unlock new weapons. Masks by the way, are a central mechanic in the game; as they supply you with your...

ABILITIES
The game is centralized around an array of animal masks; each with different names so you don't have to feel guilty for killing over a dozen people in under 30 seconds. [Yeah, it wasn't you, it was Tony. Tony the tiger.] Each mask provides a different ability that will dictate your playstyle. If you wear the Aubrey mask, for example, more guns will appear scattered around the area; whilst if you wear the Charlie mask the opposite will happen. The mask's usefulness varies quite largely; with most being practically useless and some being OP beyond belief. [All hail Tony, god of tigers and punching people into mush.] Some are also just jokes; like Phil the fish. A personal favorite of mine would have to be Brandon the panther; who might as well be Sonic the hedgehog for how fast he runs. However, if you want to get an A+ on every level, use Carl; he starts with a drill that basically doubles the points you get for ground execution. Whatever way you prefer to play, there's probably a mask for it.

VISUALS
I love me some arcade aesthetics. Hotline borrows greatly from games of old with lovingly crafted pixelated graphics that are drawn [?] pretty damn well. The bloodbath that ensues as you step into a room is gruesomely depicted as pixelated grey matter and blood are strewn about the room. Characters look very interesting, a quirk I like, as it makes all the nameless personalities you encounter easily recognizable; you'll never find yourself thinking 'is that this character or this one?' while playing. I'm a fan of the art style to say the least, and I'd like to note that this game could easily run on a toaster.

SOUNDTRACK
Amazing. A. M. A. Z. I. N. G. The soundtrack is full of many psychedelic, intense, and sometimes unnerving tracks. There couldn't be a better beat to accompany the trippy beat down that is this game. As you're constantly dying over and over again, the soundtrack is always there to give that sensation that makes you say 'I can do this!’ However, it's not all Fun & Games. As the red mist fades and you trek your way back through the bloodshed, there's a static, droning tone playing that makes it known that you've done a gruesome; terrible thing. [You psycho.]

FINAL THOUGHTS
Hotline Miami is probably one of my favorite games that's come out in recent years. It's been a while since I've experienced a game that just lets you go wild and give in to brute instinct. If I had to compare it to another game; I'd say it reminds me a bit of Dark Souls in a few ways. The gameplay is gruesome and unforgiving, though there are a few odd quirks here and there. [Enemies are blind as bats if I'm being honest.] The story is very cryptic, and doesn't provide much in the way of answers. However, a simplistic story seems to fit this type of game very well; as sometimes there just isn't a method to madness. The masks are very nice, but as I've said; half of them are useless. The ones that do change gameplay are greatly appreciated though; and can entirely change how you play. I'd rate the soundtrack alone to be honest; it's that damn good. [I'd give it a 'pudgy Italian chef kissing his fingers and muttering soemthing in Italian after he makes a dish'/10.] All in all, It's safe to say that Hotline Miami has indeed left a lasting impression; depth begins with simplistic design.

Simply put,'Should I buy this game?' has the same answer as 'Do you like hurting other people?'. So yes, you should buy this game,

reviewText: This game is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. It's a topdown super-violent action game where you control one man stuck in a crazy 16-bit world. On its head the gameplay is simple- you receive missions from a strange caller on your home phone, and head to different locations to kill everyone inside. The missions steadily grow in complexity, though, sometimes necessitating a thoughtful approach to the violence. It's super fast and visceral, with both you and enemies dying in a single hit, and with movement speeds very high, it tests your reflexes and your mettle. You get a large variety of weapons and environmental objects to kill enemies with, as well as being able to execute them with large sprays of pixelated blood. The story is your standard descent-into-madness faire, but that seems popular these days. Also of note is the game's excellent soundtrack! Heartily recommend.

reviewText:
Remember the old games that were hard and dickish? Well, Hotline Miami is hard, but is quite fair. Your enemies are killed in one hit, but so are you. Get used to dying again and again, as you will get killed a lot. It gives you moments that descisions are made in the short break between inhale and exhale.

For you bloodthirsty folks that want blood all over the place and gruesome deaths, then you have found the game, my friend. Although it gets your blood pumping and your heart racing, ít might get a bit boring after a while. It gives you that burst of addrenaline that might last for 30 minutes to an hour, but after that, you will probably take a break, then come back after an hour or two.

If you are not that skilled in über fast pased action and can kill enemies quick on the draw, this game is not for you. If you are, then why are you reading this review, you should buy the game immediately. At the low price and fair price, you should be able to afford this beautiful indie game.

9/10

reviewText:
Remember these days people? When games were just about violence?  Postal, Doom, etc.  Where it was just to murder everything in your path regardless of who it was or what it has done etc.  Well those days are gone! Now we have a game that is nothing but that! Quite litterally.

PROS:

Fun Gameplay: This game is nothing but murdering everything from the dandelions on upwards in any household that some random dude on the phone tells you to do regardless of if you want to but I guess that's because it's half the fun.  Running into some random person's building and just bashing everyones skulls in or shooting them up with a gun till all of their guts spill out or their head gets blown off.

Masks: Each mask has a different ability, which I thought was a neat little mechanic for the game since each level can be played a little differently each time with it's own abilities.  Like Dennis starts with a free knife, Peter has silent bullets but somehow some people aren't fully def or something, Ted means dogs won't even care that you're there or murdering their owners, etc.

Story: As far as the story goes it's neat I suppose, where random things happen like you get put into some room talking to 3 people wearing a horse, rooster, and owl mask which I'm STILL convinced this is basically your subconcious or something.  And later when it's hard to tell what's real and what's fake since everything seems the same with the 80's vibe around the game with the colors and areas you go to.

Soundtrack: This is one of the few things that got me into this game was the really catchy soundtrack, one of my friends showed the Knock" song to me and I instantly got hooked onto the rest of the soundtrack.  Granted some I don't really like but the large majority of them I do.  I keep hearing the 2nd game has a hit and miss soundtrack which I kind of agree on since some of the songs are great where others just sound weird and boring
date: or way too pumped instead of being the mellow music this game has.\n\nRight back in the action: Instead of going through a REALLY long loading time when you die it's a instant reload into the area with no waiting
recommended: making sure you get right back into the action without you having to get too bored and lose the tension too quickly if at all.\n\nSatisfying after levels: I was trying to be strategic in most of the levels

reviewText:
TL;DRIf you want to play a top-down, bullet hell-esque game where you try to kill everyone around you as efficiently as possible without dying yourself, then this is definitely the game for you. With the use of intense, graphic and psychedelic aesthetics and visuals; a soundtrack full of great synthwave and electronic tracks that fits the 80's Miami theme flawlessly; and gameplay that feels responsive, challenging and fun at the same time, Hotline Miami presents an experience through the bloody and bizarre world of Miami. Sure you will die alot, A LOT, but the one time you do clear the stage, it will feel magnificent.

Truly a classic in my eyes, and I would recommend it to anyone who is willing to ty it.

10 / 10

reviewText: Wasn't expecting too much going into this because I don't have nostalgia fever for 16bit graphics, but boy is this game fun. Just goes to prove you don't need super high def graphics to make a good game. Reminds me of those arcade machines where you die a lot and you curse at the machine a lot but you still keep feeding it quarters because, well, it's damn fun! The controls are very simple and easy to learn, the gameplay mechanics are fun and satisfying (basically kill all the mobsters in a level before they kill you!). Definitely worth the 2 bucks and change that it goes on sale for every so often.

reviewText: Hotline Miami does one thing very, very, well. That one thing is raw, violent, unforgiving action. The player is a killing machine facing a horde of like-minded merciless killers. Using whatever is available the player cuts, shoots, hits, beats, and decimates his opponents before they can do the same to him. It's a top-down non-stop action sequence with excellent control, instant death, very fast respawn speed (this is very important) and a mood-setting 80's dance club style soundtrack.\n\nThe story is very strange, but interesting for those who choose to follow it. Ultimately, though, the game is about the action, and it delivers it in spades. Fun, fast, furious, and engaging.

reviewText: A BLOODY GOOD TIME\n\nThis is one of my most recommended and favorite indie titles to date. Hotline Miami from a first glance, looks like every other wanna be 8-bit, retro, indie trash, that overemphasizes on the use of cheap bloody pixels. But once you get into it, it becomes so SO much more than that. The first thing that really latches you in, is the music. Any audiophile or upcoming musician, will be able to identify with the pure precision and absolute quality of this games outstanding, unique and well produced selection of techno-jazz style beats. Beats that hit hard and flow so well with the gameplay. Speaking of gameplay, this game is harshly difficult. You will die, die again, die horribly, rage, die again, die in the most pathetic way, kill another NPC then die........and so on. But death in this game is a button away. The second you die Press R to restart" appears and you are right back at your last (forgiving) checkpoint. It is enough to keep you trying time and time again
date: and subtle enough to make dying part of the gameplay in a sense. Now to the gory bits. Remember that ole "bloody pixels" thing? Well Hotline Miami is violent. Like uber violent. Like so violent
recommended: it makes you either sickly ill or sickly mad with bloodlust. Whether its slicing pixel dudes in half or popping out eyeballs; you will be surprised everytime a limb gets severed or brains get splattered(yours included). But yet again
hoursPlayed: the violence seems to mold its way into the rhythm of the soundtrack and the feedback of the gameplay. Next I guess
voteText: would be the story. Wow. Yeah. Believe it or not
helpfulPercent: this little pixelated bloodbath has one of the most complex video game storylines to date. So much so
votesHelpful: that even the character's names are clouded in mystery. The storyline of colorful animal masks and bloody jumper jackets has spurred fan fiction and even growingly popular cosplay. Hotline Miami is an absolute treat to any fan of the 80s
votesTotal: hitman themed plots and retro classics. It is a punishing and rewarding experience that will have you trying to rack up high scores and paint the screen as red as possible
votesFunny: even after you have been wasted 1000x. The seemless flow that holds it all together makes it worthy of being a AAA title. Every time you hear a skull crack open from a baseball bat while wearing a Unicorn mask and slowly watching the blood cover the screen. Just try not to smile like you enjoyed it
commentsCount:
at least not until you turn the corner and do it over........and over again.

Overall 5/5
Gameplay 5/5
Controls 4/5
Graphics 2/5
Storyline 6/5
Music 6/5

Bottom line: For $9.99 you are getting a complete title. Its unique
column16: addicting and will satisfy every aspect of what you are looking for. The game is worth twice that
column17: if you take into consideration the excellent soundtrack. You can even find this game on sale for less than $2.50 which is incredibly foolish to pass up. Buy it. You will never look at indie games the same."

Dear friends,

I have had Hotline Miami running through my mind for the past few days. The gameplay, the brutality but mostly the soundtrack. My goodness, the soundtrack. Yours in gaming,
Dubgame.

reviewText:
The atmosphere, music and feel of this game make you want to walk outside with a jockey jacket on and punch someone to death. Not out of rage at the game, but due to the sheer murderous mind the game implants into your head.

As you play this game, you will become a murderer. On the first level, the gore may creep you out a bit, but after that you wont pity any more Russian mobsters. This game will have you panicking desperately, making split second descisions and planning out your paths after the 1000th time you die. You'll feel like you're fighting for your life, but at the same time, you'll happily accept the call and go to the designated place and split open a few heads with a crowbar.

And what makes this game so intense is the extremely fast pace of it... and the music. If you walk in front on a man with a gun, you have about 0.2 seconds to kill him or you're done. All of this transforms you into a psycho for the time you are in the game. Trust me, if you are impressionable or get all pumped after watching a movie or something, please don't play this game for the safety of the people around you, because it will turn you into a murderer.

But the one thing, the main thing that is most murderous about you is the creepy as ♥♥♥♥ rubber masks. Put one on and you're a psychotic, homocidal freak.


Great game, if you're over 18, at least over 15, then you must buy it.

reviewText:
This is one of the most original and amazing games out there.

Hotline Miami it's an excelent and fast paced top-down shooter set in the neon light colorful 1989 Miami, where you play as Jacket a character that hurts people, a lot of people, the whole game is about hurting people because someone told you over the phone to do so, it's also about collecting masks that let you hurt people in many other ways.
While it's not very lengthy, it feels just right thanks to the replayability of the whole game, the levels and the chapters, alone or in it's whole. While it could be hard and frustrating at first it's an amazing and rewarding game when you get the feel of it and will be the generator of countless hours of fun while you try to achieve the highest scores and the A+ rank on every level. Add the most amazing and adrenaline inducing soundtrack of all time, and there you have it, an incredible game that will make you feel the most horrible human being for hurting so many people.

Do you like hurting other people?
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm very conflicted about whether or not I think Hotline Miami 2 is a good game, but I'm 100% certain I had a hell of a time with Hotline Miami 1. It was a blast from start to finish, and I'd say it's safe to assume it left some...

LASTING IMPRESSIONS
Hotline Miami

GENRE
Top Down Shooter-Slasher/Action

STORY
In Hotline Miami you play as the fan-named delusional psychopath Jacket. His name is Jacket due to his distinctive letterman jacket that he wears. [Glasses, jacket, shirt, call me glasses-jacket-shirt man.] When the game begins, you find yourself in a dark, dirty room with a door directly in front of you. As you step through the door, you're greeted by three figures wearing different animal masks. The woman in the horse mask seems concerned for your mental health; saying it might be better if you didn't remember your actions or identity. The man in the owl mask, dressed like a Russian mobster,  begins to yell at you; disgusted at your behavior and presence.  However, the man in the rooster mask, dressed in the same clothes you are, says he knows you. He asks if the date 'April 3rd, 1989' means anything to you. You then wake up in your rundown apartment room to the sound of a phone ringing...

GAMEPLAY
Hotline Miami is a game about pulse-pounding, high adrenaline combat. When you play you have to be on gaurd, on point, and on your toes; lest ye suffer a swift death. Everyone in this game dies in one hit; that includes you. Levels are set up by floors, with the next floor becoming accessible when you're the only person remaining with your brains firmly inside your cranium. You'll start out with your fists as weapons, but your fist can only knock enemies down onto the floor or up against walls. If you hit an enemy they'll drop their weapon; which you can promptly pick up and use to re-arrange their facial structure. Weapons range from close range objects such as bats, pipes, or knives; to long range weapons such as guns, throwing stars, or maybe even a plain old brick. [Brick too OP please nerf.] Hotline Miami is also a game about getting a good highscore; like back in the arcade ages. Each kill, maneuver, door-knockdown, execution, and combo will net you some points. It's a good idea to try and rack up a good combo and vary up your playstyle, as highscores unlock masks and points from the aforementioned scores will unlock new weapons. Masks by the way, are a central mechanic in the game; as they supply you with your...

ABILITIES
The game is centralized around an array of animal masks; each with different names so you don't have to feel guilty for killing over a dozen people in under 30 seconds. [Yeah, it wasn't you, it was Tony. Tony the tiger.] Each mask provides a different ability that will dictate your playstyle. If you wear the Aubrey mask, for example, more guns will appear scattered around the area; whilst if you wear the Charlie mask the opposite will happen. The mask's usefulness varies quite largely; with most being practically useless and some being OP beyond belief. [All hail Tony, god of tigers and punching people into mush.] Some are also just jokes; like Phil the fish. A personal favorite of mine would have to be Brandon the panther; who might as well be Sonic the hedgehog for how fast he runs. However, if you want to get an A+ on every level, use Carl; he starts with a drill that basically doubles the points you get for ground execution. Whatever way you prefer to play, there's probably a mask for it.

VISUALS
I love me some arcade aesthetics. Hotline borrows greatly from games of old with lovingly crafted pixelated graphics that are drawn [?] pretty damn well. The bloodbath that ensues as you step into a room is gruesomely depicted as pixelated grey matter and blood are strewn about the room. Characters look very interesting, a quirk I like, as it makes all the nameless personalities you encounter easily recognizable; you'll never find yourself thinking 'is that this character or this one?' while playing. I'm a fan of the art style to say the least, and I'd like to note that this game could easily run on a toaster.

SOUNDTRACK
Amazing. A. M. A. Z. I. N. G. The soundtrack is full of many psychedelic, intense, and sometimes unnerving tracks. There couldn't be a better beat to accompany the trippy beat down that is this game. As you're constantly dying over and over again, the soundtrack is always there to give that sensation that makes you say 'I can do this!’ However, it's not all Fun & Games. As the red mist fades and you trek your way back through the bloodshed, there's a static, droning tone playing that makes it known that you've done a gruesome; terrible thing. [You psycho.]

FINAL THOUGHTS
Hotline Miami is probably one of my favorite games that's come out in recent years. It's been a while since I've experienced a game that just lets you go wild and give in to brute instinct. If I had to compare it to another game; I'd say it reminds me a bit of Dark Souls in a few ways. The gameplay is gruesome and unforgiving, though there are a few odd quirks here and there. [Enemies are blind as bats if I'm being honest.] The story is very cryptic, and doesn't provide much in the way of answers. However, a simplistic story seems to fit this type of game very well; as sometimes there just isn't a method to madness. The masks are very nice, but as I've said; half of them are useless. The ones that do change gameplay are greatly appreciated though; and can entirely change how you play. I'd rate the soundtrack alone to be honest; it's that damn good. [I'd give it a 'pudgy Italian chef kissing his fingers and muttering soemthing in Italian after he makes a dish'/10.] All in all, It's safe to say that Hotline Miami has indeed left a lasting impression; depth begins with simplistic design.

Simply put,'Should I buy this game?' has the same answer as 'Do you like hurting other people?'. So yes, you should buy this game,
